newsitem.title: UK: Malaysia to arrest cocoa fall, improve processing.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia to arrest cocoa fall, improve processing.

text.p: Malaysia's cocoa crop is hitting a floor at its current 120,000-130,000 tonnes a year level after prolonged decline but output could bounce back if world prices improve sharply, the country's head of Cocoa Board said.
Musa Jamil also said Malaysia planned to improve cocoa power quality to help tide over idle grinding capacity problem and step up processing of chocolates and other finished cocoa products.

Malaysia's cocoa bean output has fallen sharply from a peak of 240,000 tonnes in the 1989/90 crop year to an estimated 110,000 in the current 1996/97 season as prolonged price slump, disease and adverse weather took their toll on production.
But Musa, speaking to Reuters on the fringes of the International Cocoa Organisation talks in London, said the slide appeared to have been arrested.
He said the existence of small but hard-core producers and the introduction of better cocoa varieties helped halt the slide.
The total area under cocoa cultivation will be kept at 215,000 hectares after falling from a high of 420,000 in 1990.
Musa said some of the higher-yielding cocoa trees in the main growing area of Tawau on Borneo island have started maturing.
"Some of the grafted trees have started bearing while others may come into maturity in two or three years," he said. "This will maintain and probably boost national production."
On grinding, Musa said the industry has been running at 100,000 tonnes of bean equivalent a year, well below its designed capacity of 125,000.
Grinders have been chasing the higher-value cocoa butter at the expense of cocoa powder, two by-products of cocoa bean.
Musa said grinders are now being encouraged to improve quality of cocoa powder in terms of colour and flavour and seek new markets to help maximise returns.
The main target markets for Malaysian cocoa powder are Turkey and Egypt.
Musa said chocolate manufacturers were also expected to step up local production in view of growing demand as income rises.
Per capita cocoa consumption is now seen at 0.7 kg a year against 0.2 kg in the late 1980s. -- London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
